elements.title: Anna Filosofova (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that after being criticized for dressing "like a doll" at an important meeting, pioneering Russian feminist Anna Filosofova (pictured) replied that "clothes do not make the woman"?

elements.title: Intermission (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Edward Hopper's 1963 painting Intermission can be viewed as a metaphor for the world as theater?

elements.title: Keira Walsh (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that footballer Keira Walsh first captained England in 2018, when she was the youngest player in the squad?

elements.title: foam depopulation (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that foam has been used to kill farm animals en masse in a process called foam depopulation?

elements.title: Jaroslav Záruba (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Jaroslav Záruba tricked a Waffen-SS unit into surrendering to the Government Army of the Protectorate of Bohemia and Moravia by falsely claiming that British troops were advancing against Prague?

elements.title: Dickwhitea (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the fossil fern Dickwhitea was described from a single block of chert?

elements.title: Andrew Dakich (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Andrew Dakich received an athletic scholarship while under police escort?

elements.title: the house featured in American Horror Story: Murder House (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that the buyers of the house featured in American Horror Story: Murder House sued its sellers for not disclosing that the house was featured on the series?

elements.title: Richard Washbourn (Wikipedia — did you know?)
elements.contents: ... that Rear Admiral Richard Washbourn bought the bell of HMS Chevron for £8 and donated it to Collingwood School?
